[Manchester United Football Club](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester
United F.C.") is an [English](/wiki/England "England")
[football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") club based in
[Old Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford,_Greater_Manchester "Old Trafford, Greater
Manchester"), [Greater Manchester](/wiki/Greater_Manchester "Greater
Manchester"). They were the first English club to enter European competition,
entering the [European Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions
League") in 1956. Since then, the club has competed in every UEFA-organised
competition, with the exception of the now-defunct [Intertoto
Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Intertoto_Cup "UEFA Intertoto Cup").

The competition in which the club has had the most success is the European Cup
(now known as the UEFA Champions League); they have won three European Cups,
the first of which came in [1968](/wiki/1968_European_Cup_Final "1968 European
Cup Final"); this win made them the first English club to win the European
Cup. The other two victories came in
[1999](/wiki/1999_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "1999 UEFA Champions League
Final") and [2008](/wiki/2008_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2008 UEFA Champions
League Final"). The club has also won the [Cup Winners'
Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup"), which they won in
[1991](/wiki/1991_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_Final "1991 European Cup
Winners' Cup Final"); the [Super Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Super_Cup "UEFA Super Cup"),
also won in [1991](/wiki/1991_European_Super_Cup "1991 European Super Cup");
the [Intercontinental Cup](/wiki/Intercontinental_Cup_\(football\)
"Intercontinental Cup \(football\)"), which they won in
[1999](/wiki/1999_Intercontinental_Cup "1999 Intercontinental Cup"); and the
[Europa League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League"), which they won
in [2017](/wiki/2017_UEFA_Europa_League_Final "2017 UEFA Europa League
Final").

After their Champions League wins in 1999 and 2008, Manchester United also
competed as UEFA's representatives at the [2000 FIFA Club World
Championship](/wiki/2000_FIFA_Club_World_Championship "2000 FIFA Club World
Championship") and the [2008 FIFA Club World
Cup](/wiki/2008_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2008 FIFA Club World Cup"). They were
knocked out of the 2000 tournament at the group stage, but went on to win the
2008 competition, becoming the first English side to do so.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Manchester_United_F.C._in_European_football&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

### Early
years[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Manchester_United_F.C._in_European_football&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early years")]

Following their league title win the previous season, Manchester United first
competed in European football competition in 1956–57. 1954–55 Football League
winners [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C.") had been denied the
opportunity to take part in the inaugural [European
Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") by [The Football
League](/wiki/The_Football_League "The Football League")'s chairman [Alan
Hardaker](/wiki/Alan_Hardaker "Alan Hardaker"), who feared that European
football would damage the integrity of the English game. However, [Matt
Busby](/wiki/Matt_Busby "Matt Busby"), the manager of Manchester United, was a
forward-thinking man and was determined to have his team compete on the
European stage. With the backing of [The Football
Association](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The Football Association")'s
chairman, [Stanley Rous](/wiki/Stanley_Rous "Stanley Rous") (who would later
go on to become the president of [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA")), Manchester United
were allowed to compete in the [1956–57 European
Cup](/wiki/1956%E2%80%9357_European_Cup "1956–57 European Cup").

The club's first match in European competition was a European Cup preliminary
round tie against [Anderlecht](/wiki/R.S.C._Anderlecht "R.S.C. Anderlecht") at
[Parc Astrid](/wiki/Constant_Vanden_Stock_Stadium "Constant Vanden Stock
Stadium") in [Brussels](/wiki/Brussels "Brussels"); Manchester United won the
match 2–0 in front of 35,000 spectators. The return leg was played at [Maine
Road](/wiki/Maine_Road "Maine Road"), the home of Manchester United's local
rivals [Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City F.C."),
as United's stadium, [Old Trafford](/wiki/Old_Trafford "Old Trafford"), had
not yet been fitted with the necessary floodlighting for evening games. The
match finished as a 10–0 win for Manchester United, a result that still stands
as the club's record win in all competitions. A long run in the European Cup
followed, including wins over [Borussia Dortmund](/wiki/Borussia_Dortmund
"Borussia Dortmund") and [Athletic Bilbao](/wiki/Athletic_Bilbao "Athletic
Bilbao") and culminating with a semi-final tie against [Real
Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid C.F."). The first leg took United
to the [Santiago Bernabéu Stadium](/wiki/Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_Stadium
"Santiago Bernabéu Stadium"), where they were defeated 3–1 in front of a
record away crowd of 135,000 spectators. However, they were only able to draw
2–2 in the second leg back at Old Trafford, and the club's first European
season came to an end as Real Madrid went on to record the second of their
five consecutive European Cup titles.

###
Munich[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Manchester_United_F.C._in_European_football&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Munich")]

Main article: [Munich air disaster](/wiki/Munich_air_disaster "Munich air
disaster")

United won the league title again that season, and were therefore eligible to
compete in the European Cup for the second consecutive year. After dispatching
[Shamrock Rovers](/wiki/Shamrock_Rovers_F.C. "Shamrock Rovers F.C.") 9–2 on
aggregate in the preliminary round, United were paired with [Dukla
Prague](/wiki/Dukla_Prague "Dukla Prague") for the first round. After the
second leg in Prague, the team was scheduled to fly back to Manchester the
following day, but fog over Manchester prevented this and they were forced to
make hasty arrangements to travel back via ferry from the [Hook of
Holland](/wiki/Hook_of_Holland "Hook of Holland") to [Harwich](/wiki/Harwich
"Harwich") and then by train up to Manchester. This long-winded journey took
its toll on the players, who were only able to manage a 1–1 away draw against
[Birmingham City](/wiki/Birmingham_City_F.C. "Birmingham City F.C.") two days
later.

Eager to avoid such a scenario again, the club's management chartered a plane
for the quarter-final second leg away to [Red Star
Belgrade](/wiki/Red_Star_Belgrade "Red Star Belgrade"). Following a 2–1 win in
the first leg at Old Trafford, a 3–3 draw in [Belgrade](/wiki/Belgrade
"Belgrade") was enough to secure passage to the semi-finals. On the return
flight to Manchester, British European Airways Flight 609 stopped over in a
snow-covered Munich for refuelling. Once the refuelling was complete, the
pilot was given clearance to take off, only to be halted by a fault with the
plane's engine. A second attempt was made a few seconds later, but the same
fault kept the plane grounded. Half an hour later, after inspection by the
airport's engineers, the plane was given clearance for another take-off
attempt. The suggested solution was to have the plane accelerate more slowly,
but this meant that the take-off velocity would not be reached until the plane
was even further down the runway. Once the plane reached 117 knots – the speed
at which it was no longer safe to abort the take-off – the pilot would have
expected the plane's velocity to continue to increase; however, there was a
sudden drop in velocity and the plane was unable to take off before the end of
the runway. It skidded off the end of the runway, through a wire fence and
across a road before crashing into a house.

The impact of the crash and the subsequent explosion of fuel killed 21 of the
44 people on board instantly, and another two died in hospital a few days
later. Eight of those who died were Manchester United players, among them
[Duncan Edwards](/wiki/Duncan_Edwards "Duncan Edwards"), [Roger
Byrne](/wiki/Roger_Byrne "Roger Byrne") and [Tommy Taylor](/wiki/Tommy_Taylor
"Tommy Taylor"), while club secretary [Walter Crickmer](/wiki/Walter_Crickmer
"Walter Crickmer"), trainer [Tom Curry](/wiki/Tom_Curry "Tom Curry") and coach
[Bert Whalley](/wiki/Bert_Whalley "Bert Whalley") were also killed. Matt Busby
was also severely injured, but he made a full recovery after two months in
hospital. With eight of the club's first team having been killed in the
accident, and several more still recuperating, a threadbare side took to the
field for the semi-final matches against [Milan](/wiki/A.C._Milan "A.C.
Milan"). A 2–1 win at Old Trafford in the first leg gave the team hope of a
place in the final, but a 4–0 defeat back at the [San Siro](/wiki/San_Siro
"San Siro") put paid to those dreams. In honour of those who died, UEFA
offered United a berth in the [1958–59 European
Cup](/wiki/1958%E2%80%9359_European_Cup "1958–59 European Cup"), drawing them
against [BSC Young Boys](/wiki/BSC_Young_Boys "BSC Young Boys") in the
preliminary round, but the Football League denied United entry to the
competition as they had not won the Football League the previous season after
their league campaign crumbled in the aftermath of the disaster.

### Return to
Europe[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Manchester_United_F.C._in_European_football&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Return to Europe")]

Victory in the [1962–63 FA Cup](/wiki/1962%E2%80%9363_FA_Cup "1962–63 FA Cup")
meant that United returned to European competition after a five-year absence
for the [1963–64 Cup Winners'
Cup](/wiki/1963%E2%80%9364_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "1963–64 European Cup
Winners' Cup"). After sweeping aside [Willem
II](/wiki/Willem_II_\(football_club\) "Willem II \(football club\)") of the
[Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands") and the defending champions,
England's [Tottenham Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur
F.C."), United were drawn against [Sporting
CP](/wiki/Sporting_Clube_de_Portugal "Sporting Clube de Portugal") in the
quarter-finals. A 4–1 home win in the first leg meant that United needed to
avoid defeat by more than three goals at [Estádio José
Alvalade](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_Jos%C3%A9_Alvalade "Estádio José Alvalade") to
progress to the semi-finals; however, the team succumbed to their heaviest
defeat in European competition to date, losing 5–0 on the night and 6–4 on
aggregate.

A second-place finish in the league in 1963–64 meant that United qualified for
the [Inter-Cities Fairs Cup](/wiki/Inter-Cities_Fairs_Cup "Inter-Cities Fairs
Cup") in [1964–65](/wiki/1964%E2%80%9365_Inter-Cities_Fairs_Cup "1964–65
Inter-Cities Fairs Cup"). They reached the semi-finals, knocking out
[Djurgården](/wiki/Djurg%C3%A5rdens_IF_Fotboll "Djurgårdens IF Fotboll"),
Borussia Dortmund, [Everton](/wiki/Everton_F.C. "Everton F.C.") and
[Strasbourg](/wiki/RC_Strasbourg "RC Strasbourg") before losing 2–1 to
[Ferencváros](/wiki/Ferencv%C3%A1rosi_TC "Ferencvárosi TC") in a play-off
after a 3–3 aggregate draw over two legs.

### Back in the European
Cup[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Manchester_United_F.C._in_European_football&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Back in the European Cup")]

The following season saw United return to the European Cup for the first time
since Munich after they had beaten [Leeds United](/wiki/Leeds_United_A.F.C.
"Leeds United A.F.C.") to top spot in the Football League on [goal
average](/wiki/Goal_difference "Goal difference"). After seeing off
[Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland")'s [HJK
Helsinki](/wiki/Helsingin_Jalkapalloklubi "Helsingin Jalkapalloklubi") and
[Vorwärts Berlin](/wiki/Frankfurter_FC_Viktoria "Frankfurter FC Viktoria") of
[East Germany](/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany") in the first two rounds,
Manchester United were drawn against four-time finalists, two-time winners and
the previous season's runners-up, [Benfica](/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L.
Benfica"). Benfica's most famous player, the [Portuguese](/wiki/Portugal
"Portugal") international [Eusébio](/wiki/Eus%C3%A9bio "Eusébio"), had just
been named the [European Footballer of the
Year](/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or_\(1956%E2%80%932009\) "Ballon d'Or \(1956–2009\)")
and his team went into the tie as favourites. Despite this tag, United ran out
3–2 winners in the first leg at Old Trafford, before beating the Lisbon side
5–1 back at the [Estádio da Luz](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_da_Luz_\(1954\) "Estádio
da Luz \(1954\)"), in what is considered to be the greatest match of [George
Best](/wiki/George_Best "George Best")'s career.[1][2][3] The result set up a
semi-final tie with [Partizan](/wiki/FK_Partizan "FK Partizan"), a tie that
would take United back to for the first time since the tragedy in Munich. Best
had injured his knee in an [FA Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup") Sixth Round match
against [Preston North End](/wiki/Preston_North_End_F.C. "Preston North End
F.C.") a couple of weeks before, and although he played in the first leg
against Partizan, he was not fully fit and United struggled, losing 2–0 at the
[JNA Stadium](/wiki/Partizan_Stadium "Partizan Stadium"). A goal from [Nobby
Stiles](/wiki/Nobby_Stiles "Nobby Stiles") secured a 1–0 win in the second leg
back at Old Trafford, but it was not enough and Matt Busby, believing that his
dream of winning the European Cup was over, considered retirement; however, he
resolved to win another league title and have one last shot at Europe's
biggest prize.

### First European
title[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Manchester_United_F.C._in_European_football&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: First European title")]

Manchester United won the [1966–67 Football
League](/wiki/1966%E2%80%9367_Football_League "1966–67 Football League") title
by four points over [Nottingham Forest](/wiki/Nottingham_Forest_F.C.
"Nottingham Forest F.C.") with a game to spare; this secured their second
European Cup appearance in three seasons for
[1967–68](/wiki/1967%E2%80%9368_European_Cup "1967–68 European Cup"). After
overcoming the Maltese champions, [Hibernians](/wiki/Hibernians_F.C.
"Hibernians F.C."), in the first round, United were handed yet another trip to
Yugoslavia, this time to take on [FK Sarajevo](/wiki/FK_Sarajevo "FK
Sarajevo"). The Red Devils faced a long journey to [Sarajevo](/wiki/Sarajevo
"Sarajevo") for the first leg, and they were held to a 0–0 draw in a very
physical match. The second leg was equally robust, but United took control of
the tie with goals from [John Aston](/wiki/John_Aston,_Jr. "John Aston, Jr.")
and George Best. Sarajevo were only able to pull back one goal and United went
through to the quarter-finals, where they were drawn against Polish side
[Górnik Zabrze](/wiki/G%C3%B3rnik_Zabrze "Górnik Zabrze"). United won the
first leg at Old Trafford 2–0; an [own goal](/wiki/Own_goal "Own goal") from
[Stefan Florenski](/wiki/Stefan_Florenski "Stefan Florenski") put them 1–0 up
after an hour, and [Brian Kidd](/wiki/Brian_Kidd "Brian Kidd") doubled their
lead in the final minute. The Poles had come to be considered one of the
better sides in the last eight, and they were able to come away with a 1–0 win
in the second leg, but it was not enough to prevent United from progressing to
a semi-final tie with [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_C.F. "Real Madrid
C.F."). United's 1–0 win in the first leg at Old Trafford was all that
separated the sides after a 3–3 draw at the Bernabéu, setting up a meeting
with Benfica in the final at [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_\(1923\)
"Wembley Stadium \(1923\)"). Best was again on the scoresheet, along with two
goals from Charlton and one from Kidd on his 19th birthday, as United beat the
Portuguese champions 4–1 after extra time to claim their first European
trophy.

United reached the semi-finals of the European Cup as holders in the 1968–69
season, but lost to Milan. They would not compete in Europe for another seven
years.

### European
comeback[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Manchester_United_F.C._in_European_football&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: European comeback")]

Following the retirement of Sir Matt Busby as manager at the end of the
1968–69 season, United entered a barren period that culminated in relegation
to the Second Division in 1974. Promotion was achieved at the first attempt
under the management of [Tommy Docherty](/wiki/Tommy_Docherty "Tommy
Docherty"), who had taken over in December 1972, and in that first season back
in the top flight, United finished third in the league to qualify for the
[UEFA Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League").

Although United did qualify for the European Cup Winners' Cup as FA Cup
winners in 1977 and for the UEFA Cup in 1980 and 1982 with top-five finishes,
they failed to make an impact on European competitions until the 1983–84
season, when they qualified for the European Cup Winners' Cup as FA Cup
winners under [Ron Atkinson](/wiki/Ron_Atkinson "Ron Atkinson"). The United
squad of this era was arguably the finest of the post-Busby era, containing
star players including [Ray Wilkins](/wiki/Ray_Wilkins "Ray Wilkins"), [Bryan
Robson](/wiki/Bryan_Robson "Bryan Robson"), [Frank
Stapleton](/wiki/Frank_Stapleton "Frank Stapleton") and teenage forward
[Norman Whiteside](/wiki/Norman_Whiteside "Norman Whiteside"). United achieved
a famous victory over [Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") in the
quarter-finals of the [1983–84 European Cup Winners'
Cup](/wiki/1983%E2%80%9384_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "1983–84 European Cup
Winners' Cup"), winning the second leg 3–0 at Old Trafford after being beaten
2–0 in Spain in the first leg, made all the more impressive by the fact that
Barcelona's team contained [Diego Maradona](/wiki/Diego_Maradona "Diego
Maradona"), rated by many as the best footballer in the world at the time.

United reached the quarter-finals of the UEFA Cup in 1984–85, but this would
be their last contribution to European football for half a decade; the
subsequent [Heysel Stadium disaster](/wiki/Heysel_Stadium_disaster "Heysel
Stadium disaster") at the European Cup final, in which rioting by
[Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C. "Liverpool F.C.") fans resulted in the death
of 39 spectators and led to a ban on all English clubs in European
competitions which would not be lifted in 1990. This resulted in United
missing out on qualification for the European Cup Winners' Cup in 1985, and
the UEFA Cup in 1986 and 1988. During this exile from Europe, United replaced
Ron Atkinson with [Alex Ferguson](/wiki/Alex_Ferguson "Alex Ferguson") as
their manager, and he remained in charge more than a quarter of a century
later.

### Since
1990[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Manchester_United_F.C._in_European_football&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Since 1990")]

[![Three silver trophies on blue plinths in a glass display
case.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/PalmaresManU.jpg/170px-
PalmaresManU.jpg)](/wiki/File:PalmaresManU.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PalmaresManU.jpg "Enlarge")

Manchester United won a [treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\) "Treble
\(association football\)") in 1999: the [Premier League](/wiki/Premier_League
"Premier League"), [Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA
Champions League") and [FA Cup](/wiki/FA_Cup "FA Cup") _(left to right)_ ; the
English club also won the [1999 Intercontinental
Cup](/wiki/1999_Intercontinental_Cup "1999 Intercontinental Cup").

When the ban on English clubs in European competitions was lifted for the
1990–91 season, United were England's representatives in the European Cup
Winners' Cup, as FA Cup winners, and they marked their return to Europe by
winning the competition, with a 2–1 win over Barcelona (by now without
Maradona) in the [final](/wiki/1991_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_Final "1991
European Cup Winners' Cup Final"), in which [Mark Hughes](/wiki/Mark_Hughes
"Mark Hughes") scored twice.[4] Their defence of the trophy in the 1991–92
season was short-lived, ending at the hands of [Atlético
Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético Madrid") in the second round, and
they lost at the first hurdle in the [1992–93 UEFA
Cup](/wiki/1992%E2%80%9393_UEFA_Cup "1992–93 UEFA Cup"). League title glory in
1993 saw United enter the European Cup (now branded the Champions League) for
the first time in 25 years, but in spite of their excellent domestic form
during this era, they failed to make much of an impact in European
competitions until the 1996–97 season, when they reached the semi-finals of
the Champions League and were beaten by Borussia Dortmund. This campaign in
Europe also saw them suffer their first defeat home in a European competition,
40 years after first competing on the continent, losing 1–0 to Turkish side
[Fenerbahçe](/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_S.K. "Fenerbahçe S.K.") in the group
stage.[5]

They finally ended a 31-year wait for a second European Cup in 1999 when
stoppage-time goals from [Teddy Sheringham](/wiki/Teddy_Sheringham "Teddy
Sheringham") and [Ole Gunnar Solskjær](/wiki/Ole_Gunnar_Solskj%C3%A6r "Ole
Gunnar Solskjær") gave them a 2–1 win over [Bayern
Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich") in the
[final](/wiki/1999_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "1999 UEFA Champions League
Final") in Barcelona.[6] In 2003–04, United were beaten by
[Porto](/wiki/FC_Porto "FC Porto") in the last 16 of the Champions League,
ending a seven-year run of quarter-final appearances in the competitions,[7]
which also included one run to the final and a further two to the semi-finals.

After three short-lived Champions League campaigns, United made an impact on
the competition in the 2006–07 season. After going down 2–1 in Italy to
[Roma](/wiki/A.S._Roma "A.S. Roma") in the quarter-final first leg,[8] they
triumphed 7–1 in the second leg to reach the semi-finals for the first time in
five years.[9] They took a 3–2 lead against Milan in the first leg,[10] only
for their hopes of an all-English final with Liverpool to be ended by a 3–0
second leg defeat.[11] A year later, however, they won the trophy for the
third time, beating fellow English side Chelsea on penalties in Moscow after a
1–1 draw in the first all-English European Cup
[final](/wiki/2008_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2008 UEFA Champions League
Final").[12]

[![A photograph of three medals sitting on a stand. One medal is gold and two
are
silver.](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9c/Manchester_United_Champions_League_Medals.jpg/220px-
Manchester_United_Champions_League_Medals.jpg)](/wiki/File:Manchester_United_Champions_League_Medals.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Manchester_United_Champions_League_Medals.jpg "Enlarge")

Winners' and runners-up medals from Manchester United's UEFA Champions League
final appearances in 2008, 2009 and 2011

United reached two European Cup finals in the next three years, but lost to
Barcelona on both occasions; first in the [2009
final](/wiki/2009_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2009 UEFA Champions League
Final") in Rome,[13] and then in the [2011
final](/wiki/2011_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2011 UEFA Champions League
Final") at the new [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium")
in London.[14] After finishing seventh in the Premier League in 2013–14 under
[David Moyes](/wiki/David_Moyes "David Moyes"), United missed out on European
football in 2014–15 for the first time in 25 years,[15] but returned to
European action the following season after Moyes' replacement [Louis van
Gaal](/wiki/Louis_van_Gaal "Louis van Gaal") guided the club to fourth in the
league and a place in the [Champions League play-off
round](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_UEFA_Champions_League#Play-off_round "2015–16
UEFA Champions League").[16] It was the first time that Manchester United had
played in the qualifying phase of the Champions League since beating Hungarian
side [Debrecen](/wiki/Debreceni_VSC "Debreceni VSC") in the [2005–06
competition](/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_UEFA_Champions_League "2005–06 UEFA
Champions League").[17]
